body:
Concept ACK, thanks for working on this.

Wouldn't it be preferable to ask `git` directly with `git submodule status` instead of looking for `.gitmodules` (which is an implementation detail)?
Concept ACK.

Concept ACK
Agree with @laanwj. Looking for .gitmodule feels like a tiny layer violation.
Ok, will switch to a git(1) based solution. Don't have that much time today so I don't know if I can do it right now.

Updated the script with a git based solution.
If a submodule was found it'll look like this (I used https://github.com/curl/curl.git in this example)
```
Delete the submodules:
5ce7102ceae250e2d31b54aad2f33b3bc35f243a curl (curl-7_68_0-99-g5ce7102ce)
```
utACK bb01963663d6f20ccb8966f3d4c0f8d4e0007cd4
Squashed
ACK 1b29eee3f29fd835a83488c855d4cf5a6a4ab4df

Thanks for updating this to use git
ACK
ACK 2a95c7c95690112a03b14ccb0fb8f66db12cb75b

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/bin/sh
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(find . -type f | grep .gitmodules)
+RESULT=$?
+if [ $RESULT = 0 ]
+then
+    echo Delete the submodules:
+    echo $CMD
+    EXIT_CODE=1
+fi
+
+exit $EXIT_CODE
body: nit, add newline.

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@

+

body: What if this is executed in test folder?

Why use bash for it?
sh does the same and is more cross platform

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@

body: Then it will only look for .gitmodules in the test folder. Is there a way to go to the root dir?

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@

+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying

body: It will be nice having here a description (smth like "`# Check for git submodules.`") following an empty line (see other scripts in this subdir as an example).

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(git submodule status --recursive)
body:
```suggestion
CMD=$(git submodule status)
```

If this script reports submodules which should be _deleted_, it should not list nested ones.

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(git submodule status --recursive)
+if [[ ${CMD} ]]
+then
body:
nit: `if test -n "$CMD"; then` seems more explicit.
nit: curly braces are redundant here.

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(git submodule status --recursive)
+if [[ ${CMD} ]]
+then
+    echo These submodules were found, delete them:
+    echo $CMD
body:
```suggestion
    echo "$CMD"
```

...otherwise, script will print multiple submodules in a line.

body: Why? Submodule is submodule?

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,18 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env bash
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2020 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+export LC_ALL=C
+EXIT_CODE=0
+
+CMD=$(git submodule status --recursive)
body:
If an "outer" submodule will be deleted, the nested submodule will be deleted automatically (as it resides in the subdirectory of the "outer" submodule), no?

It seems no need in "delete them" instruction to a user point to nested submodules.

body: post-hom: Probably should leave a sentence saying why it's erroring if it does and what the alternative is for implementers :)
